content.caption: A word to summarize Maine in 2016? How about "divided." From a historic presidential election that saw the state cleave along party lines to a national monument that incited clashes about our state’s past, present and future, this year Maine only seemed to agree on disagreement.

Marijuana was made legal, too, but only by the narrowest margin. Inflammatory, impassioned rhetoric from our elected leaders and literary giants, about politics, race, culture and crime, highlighted and amplified divisions within our state and country.

Amid all this, though, unity was present if elusive. Maine was gripped by an arrest in a notable cold case murder. We mourned the boy who was lost, and reveled in a serpentine spectacle along the Presumpscot River.

Together, we learned that deals for electricity aren’t as good as they seem, that state spending must be scrutinized so it goes where it belongs, and that pleasing distractions of winter in Portland and late summer in Bangor can leave to never return.
We, again, mourned too many Mainers lost to heroin.
The top stories of 2016, listed here, reflect these divisions, but not at the expense of the moments that united us. Over the coming year, here’s hoping to much more of the latter.

One could see it coming, like Katahdin on the horizon. By the time President Barack Obama designated the Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument on August 24, it had a lobbyist, a logo, a paper trail of curious other land deals, and most telling, the monument land had been deeded to the federal government the prior day. This action closes a lengthy chapter in Maine history, but questions remain. For now, the monument exists as a testament to patience, politics, and perhaps, future prosperity for a region needing it.

One person in Maine per day, on average, dies of a heroin overdose. In February, the BDN’s Erin Rhoda produced an exhaustive look at why, through the eyes of Garrett Brown, whom she had known, followed and come to understand over 2½ years. Her piece resonated widely and prompted real action on solutions, yet the scourge remains unchecked. Heroin is killing more Mainers than car crashes. Those who are left behind are devastated. Not enough treatment exists, although the state’s recent infusion of $2.5 million is laudable, if overdue. Yet more must be done. This disease, these drugs, and the hopelessness they cause are killing Maine.

A young woman, Joyce McClain, was mysteriously murdered in East Millinocket in 1980. In a small town, secrets are few and rumors abound, yet what was apparently missing for 36 years -- according to police -- was enough facts to charge a suspect. That changed, all of a sudden, on a bitterly cold day in March when Philip Scott Fournier was led away in handcuffs. One could almost feel the town’s deep exhale on the winter wind that day. For the McClain family, their solemn vigil has ended, for now. Fournier is expected to go to trial in 2017.

"As Maine goes, so goes the nation" was never truer than 2016. Our state mirrored all the trends: the power of the progressive left in the Democratic caucuses and the divided conservatives in the Republican. Then, an unpredictable candidate whose rhetoric and rise drew comparisons, and the early endorsement, of Gov. Paul LePage won a shocking victory. Most important, though, were the deep splits these politics revealed in Maine, particularly between coastal and inland counties and congressional districts. Given all this, another old saying rings true: There are actually two Maines. This year seemed to prove it.

The effect of recent welfare policy changes in Maine boils down to three key phrases: fewer benefits, for fewer dollars, for fewer people. We’re now starting to understand the risks -- and the temptations -- of changing a system meant to help the neediest among us. Matthew Stone of the BDN found out the state was misspending money meant for poor families. This transgression was not only unlawful, but came about because the state elected to quietly bank millions in federal funds earmarked for these families -- not spend it to support them. In a rural state with low incomes and a toughening economy, this practice comes at a high cost.

Not all heroes wear capes. Some crawl on their bellies in the underbrush near the Presumpscot River, shed amazingly long skins, and captivate a community in the process. Wessie the anaconda, for a brief time this summer, was a fearful monster, amazing novelty, a social media sensation and, ultimately, a symbol that united Westbrook. Given anacondas’ sensitivity to cold weather, though, it’s presumed Wessie has slithered from this mortal coil. The legend lives on.

Unlike the other four citizen-initiated ballot questions of 2016, none promises a more social, cultural and visceral effect on Maine than the legalization of marijuana. Although Mainers have had an electorally and regulatorily relaxed attitude toward pot, this bid for legalization against the backdrop of a full-blown drug crisis emerged deeply divided. It passed by a razor’s edge after a recount, leaving proponents and opponents entrenched and the future implementation of the law shrouded in a haze. Lawmakers are mulling changes and the governor is not a fan. Legal weed might be in the weeds for awhile.

Time and time again in 2016, the lexicon of elected officials -- in public settings and private voicemails -- elicited intense controversy and deepened divisions. Crude, unseemly remarks about race, drugs and crime uttered by Gov. LePage during his town hall tour, for example, gave rise to protests. His subsequent recorded tirade against a Democratic lawmaker fueled calls for his resignation. LePage wears the plainspoken badge proudly. Yet while we may argue passionately -- and sometimes harshly -- about our political differences, what our elected officials say says a lot about Maine. This year's coarse discourse did not reflect well on the state's values, or its people.

We should remember Donn Fendler not for getting lost on a mountain in Maine, but for devoting his life to ensuring other kids never would. His stirring tale of survival is as incredible today as in 1939, when the starving pre-teen emerged from the wilderness with a wild story that raced across the globe. Then, for subsequent decades, he told and retold it for the purpose of ensuring his lesson -- not his name, or his fame -- was preserved. Fendler touched generations of Mainers, all of whom mourned his passing. The boy who was lost found his calling, and for that, we’re eternally grateful.

On a postcard, or over the phone, the deal sounds great: Cheaper, cleaner energy than one can procure from the power company, if you sign up today. Who wouldn’t want it? Thousand of Mainers did, and ended up paying the price. Darren Fishell of the BDN spent months analyzing public records and electricity prices to uncover that private power companies gouged their customers for $50 million they didn’t need to spend in just a few years. This reporting has sparked a class-action lawsuit and scrutiny of these providers in other states. It should serve as a strong reminder to always check the fine print.

Nothing lasts forever, as Portland and Bangor learned. The Senior League World Series, a staple of late summer in the Queen City, pulled up stakes. The Portland Pirates left the Forest City in a lurch after taxpayers invested millions in its arena. In this latter void, UMaine is trying to fill a city’s appetite for sport. Hopefully too, an interruption to the silence of Mansfield Stadium in August is also found.

The reason so many tourists stand before Stephen King’s wrought-iron gates on his West Broadway home is because, beyond them, an elusive master of mystery and horror resides. Well, this year, King was anything but elusive, thanks to social media and the prominent figment of his imagination -- Pennywise, the terrorizing clown of Derry nee Bangor in "It" -- becoming alive and terrifying. King had some great achievements this year, too, with a professorship at UMaine named for him, along with a book of writing from his student years there finally published. But this year, dear readers, will be remembered for King’s political commentary, his clowning achievement, and his corgi puppy Molly, aka, The Thing of Evil. No more standing at the gates. This year, King let us all inside.
